options.text: A minute vessel running parallel to Henle's loop forming a U-shaped structure

questions.text: What is the functional significance of selective secretion in renal tubules?

options.text: To maintain ionic and acid-base balance of body fluids

questions.text: How does the strategic location of JGA at the junction of DCT and afferent arteriole benefit its regulatory function?

options.text: It allows sensing of both tubular fluid composition and arteriolar ZBLood flow for coordinated GFR regulation

options.text: Production of lesser toxic nitrogenous wastes like urea and uric acid for water conservation

questions.text: A person is undergoing prolonged fasting. His urine will be found to contain abnormal quantities of:
Which one of the following correctly explains the function of a specific part of a human nephron?

options.text: Podocytes create minute spaces (slite pores) for the filtration of blood into the Bowman's capsule
Henle's loop most reabsorption of the major substances from the glomerular filtrate
Distal convoluted tubule: reabsorption of K^+ ions into the surrounding blood capillaries
Afferent arteriole: carries the blood away from the glomerular towards renal vein.

questions.text: Under normal conditions which one is completely reabsorbed in the renal tubule?

options.text: Reabsorption of $Na^{+}$ and water from renal tubules due to aldosterone
Decrease in secretion of renin by JG cells
More water reabsorption due to undersecretion of ADH

ammonia in tadpole and urea in adult frog
urea in both tadpole and adult frog
urea in tadpole and uric acid in adult frog

options.text: Decreased bone mass and increased chances of fractures

questions.text: How does the genetic basis of muscular dystrophy lead to progressive muscle degeneration?

options.text: Genetic defect in dystrophin protein compromises muscle membrane integrity causing ongoing damage

questions.text: How many cervical vertebrae are present in the human vertebral column?
What would happen to muscle contraction if ATP was depleted, and why does this explain rigor mortis?

options.text: Cross-bridges cannot detach without ATP, causing permanent contraction (rigor mortis)

questions.text: How many metacarpal bones (palm bones) are present in each hand?
How does the difference between white and red muscle fibers reflect different functional specializations?

options.text: Red fibers specialize in sustained aerobic work; white fibers in rapid anaerobic bursts

questions.text: How does the property of muscle extensibility complement contractility for effective movement?

options.text: Extensibility allows muscles to lengthen when antagonists contract; contractility shortens them - enaZBLing reciprocal movement

options.text: Binds to troponin to remove the masking of active sites on actin for myosin.
Activates the myosin ATPase by binding to it.
Prevents the formation of bonds between the myosin cross bridges and the actin filament.
Detaches the myosin head from the actin filament.

options.text: The central gap between myosin filaments in the A-band.

The absence of myofibrils in the central portion of A-band.

questions.text: During muscle contraction in humans the

options.text: A, H and I bands shorten

options.text: Actin and Myosin filaments shorten and slide pass each other

The moment of inertia of remaining part of bigger disc about an axis AB passing through the centre O and perpendicular to the plane of disc is $(4/x) \cdot M \cdot R^2$. The value of x is ________.

A simple pendulum of length 1 m has a wooden bob of mass 1 kg. It is struck by a bullet of mass $10^{-2}$ kg moving with a speed of $2 \times 10^2$ m/s. The bullet gets embedded into the bob. The height to which the bob rises before swinging back is (use $g = 10 m/s^2$):

A thin solid disk of 1 kg is rotating along its diameter axis at the speed of 1800 rpm. By applying an external torque of $25\pi$ Nm for 40 s, the speed increases to 2100 rpm. The diameter of the disk is ________ m.

The identical spheres each of mass 2M are placed at the corners of a right angled triangle with mutually perpendicular sides equal to 4 m each. Taking point of intersection of these two sides as origin, the magnitude of position vector of the centre of mass of the system is $(4\sqrt{2})/x$ m, where the value of x is:

A ring and a solid sphere roll down the same inclined plane without slipping. They start from rest. The radii of both bodies are identical and the ratio of their kinetic energies is 7/x where x is _____
A solid circular disc of mass 50 kg rolls along a horizontal floor so that its center of mass has a speed of 0.4 m/s. The absolute value of work done on the disc to stop it is (in Joules):

A uniform circular disc of radius 'R' and mass 'M' is rotating about an axis perpendicular to its plane and passing through its centre. A small circular part of radius $R/2$ is removed from the original disc as shown in the figure. Find the moment of inertia of the remaining part of the original disc about the axis as given above.

A solid sphere and a hollow cylinder roll up without slipping on same inclined plane with same initial speed v. The sphere and the cylinder reaches upto maximum heights $h_1$ and $h_2$, respectively, above the initial level. The ratio $h_1:h_2$ is n/10. The value of n is:

A thin circular disc of mass M and radius R is rotating in a horizontal plane about an axis passing through its centre and perpendicular to its plane with angular velocity $\omega$. If another disc of same dimensions but of mass M/2 is placed gently on the first disc co-axially, then the new angular velocity of the system is:

The position vectors of two 1 kg particles, (A) and (B), are given by $\vec{r}_A = (\alpha_1t^2\hat{i} + \alpha_2t\hat{j} + \alpha_3t\hat{k})$ m and $\vec{r}_B = (\beta_1t\hat{i} + \beta_2t^2\hat{j} + \beta_3t\hat{k})$ m, respectively; $(\alpha_1 = 1 m/s^2, \alpha_2 = 3n m/s, \alpha_3 = 2 m/s, \beta_1 = 2 m/s, \beta_2 = -1 m/s^2, \beta_3 = 4p m/s)$, where t is time, n and p are constants. At $t = 1$ s, velocities $|\vec{V}_A|$ and $|\vec{V}_B|$ of the particles are orthogonal to each other. At $t = 1$ s, the magnitude of angular momentum of particle (A) with respect to the position of particle (B) is $\sqrt{L} kgm^2s^{-1}$. The value of L is _______.

A solid sphere of mass 'm' and radius 'r' is allowed to roll without slipping from the highest point of an inclined plane of length 'L' and makes an angle $30$ with the horizontal. The speed of the particle at the bottom of the plane is $v_1$. If the angle of inclination is increased to $45$ while keeping constant L. Then the new speed of the sphere at the bottom of the plane is $v_2$. The ratio $v_1^2 : v_2^2$ is

In a system two particles of masses $m_1 = 3$ kg and $m_2 = 2$ kg are placed at certain distance from each other. The particle of mass $m_1$ is moved towards the center of mass of the system through a distance 2 cm. In order to keep the center of mass of the system at the original position, the particle of mass $m_2$ should move towards the center of mass by the distance:
Ratio of radius of gyration of a hollow sphere to that of a solid cylinder of equal mass, for moment of Inertia about their diameter axis as shown in figure is $\sqrt{8/x}$. The value of x is:

A wheel of radius 0.2 m rotates freely about its center when a string that is wrapped over its rim is pulled by force of 10 N as shown in figure. The established torque produces an angular acceleration of 2 rad/s$^2$. Moment of inertia of the wheel is _____ kgm$^2$. (Acceleration due to gravity = 10 m/s$^2$)

A string is wrapped around the rim of a wheel of moment of inertia $0.40 kg \cdot m^2$ and radius 10 cm. The wheel is free to rotate about its axis. Initially the wheel is at rest. The string is now pulled by a force of 40 N. The angular velocity of the wheel after 10 s is x rad/s, where x is:
A cylinder is rolling down on an inclined plane of inclination $60^\circ$. Its acceleration during rolling down will be $x\sqrt{3}$ m/s$^2$, where _____ (use $g = 10 m/s^2$).

A, B and C are disc, solid sphere and spherical shell respectively with same radii and masses. These masses are placed as shown in figure. The moment of inertia of the given system about PQ is $(X/15) \cdot I$, where I is the moment of inertia of the disc about its diameter. The value of x is _______.

Consider a Disc of mass 5 kg, radius 2 m, rotating with angular velocity of 10 rad/s about an axis perpendicular to the plane of rotation. An identical disc is kept gently over the rotating disc along the same axis. The energy dissipated so that both the discs continue to rotate together without slipping is_____ J.
